posts.post_content:
This is easily the most powerful of the core set uncommon color-hate cycle. [Deathmark](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Deathmark) might be cheaper, but it's sorcery speed, limited to creatures, and impotent against regerators or invulnerable creatures.  
  
Like I said in my comment on [Oblivion Ring](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Oblivion Ring), white is R&D's love child. This is totally 3-4x sideboard tech in any deck with white.
posts.html:

Posted By: Diabloboy (11/20/2011 10:01:52 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Compare to [Devout Lightcaster](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Devout Lightcaster). I call bull shit on this card. Moreover, look at its first printing- CONFLUX!!! The same set as NICOL BOLAS, PLANESWALKER.   
  
OK- so every card needs an answer. Fine, I can accept that. But this is too much. It's too good, too versatile, too unmerciful. This card half-ruined how awesome Nicol Bolas was supposed to be. In the end, he got less respect than Phyrexian Obliterator as 'posterboy of the set' Mythic Rare. Nicol Bolas is strictly for casual, whereas Phyrexian Obliterator can and does show up in older formats, especially where they allow Dark Ritual. Oblivion Ring does everything Celestial Purge does, plus a little more fairness.
posts.html:

Posted By: DarthParallax (11/11/2011 7:31:49 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I don't like just how much better the white hate card is in the core sets.  
White can deal with any permanent after it hits the board and at instant speed.  
Blue must draw their hate spell before the opponent plays their spell, but it can deal with anything including instant and sorcerys.  
Black is sorcery speed and can only hit creatures.  
Red, while instant, only deals damage to creatures, so large creatures can survive.  
Green gets a crappy anti-counterspell/anti-spot removal that still must be drawn before an opponent casts their spell.  
  
Seems like they could have balanced them just a little better is all.
posts.html:
I don't like just how much better the white hate card is in the core sets.
White can deal with any permanent after it hits the board and at instant speed.
Blue must draw their hate spell before the opponent plays their spell, but it can deal with anything including instant and sorcerys.
Black is sorcery speed and can only hit creatures.
Red, while instant, only deals damage to creatures, so large creatures can survive.
Green gets a crappy anti-counterspell/anti-spot removal that still must be drawn before an opponent casts their spell.

Seems like they could have balanced them just a little better is all.
